THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

        The State, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Terrence Damon Johnson, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS 

Appeal From Charleston County
Â A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2005-MO-011
Submitted March 21, 2005 â€“ Filed April 11, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED IN PART


  
    
      
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Petitioner
        Anthony B. Oâ€™Neill, Sr., Esquire, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Prior to being tried on various drug charges, respondent successfully moved to suppress evidence of the drugs, arguing they had been obtained pursuant to an illegal seizure.Â  The Court of Appeals upheld the Circuit Courtâ€™s finding that respondent was unlawfully detained by police.Â  However, the Court of Appeals remanded the case to the Circuit Court for a specific ruling on whether respondent voluntarily consented to the search of his vehicle notwithstanding the illegal seizure.Â  State v. Johnson, Op. No. 2003-UP-757 (S.C. Ct. App. filed December 23, 2003).
Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ ruling that respondent was unlawfully detained by police.Â  Additionally, petitioner seeks review of the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision to remand the case to the Circuit Court for a specific ruling on whether respondent voluntarily consented to the search of his vehicle.
We agree respondent was subject to an unlawful seizure.Â  Furthermore, we hold the Circuit Courtâ€™s ruling includes a determination that respondentâ€™s consent to the search of his vehicle was not voluntary.Â  Accordingly, we grant the petition for a writ of certiorari, dispense with further briefing, affirm the Court of Appealsâ€™ finding of an illegal seizure, and vacate that portion of the decision which remands the case to the Circuit Court.
AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

 Counsel for petitioner has filed a petition for a writ of certiorari, pursuant to Johnson v. State, 294 S.C. 310, 364 S.E.2d 201 (1988), from an order of the circuit court denying petitionerâ€™s request for a writ of habeas corpus.Â  Because the procedure set forth in Johnson is not applicable in habeas corpus actions, we construe this matter as a direct appeal from the order of the circuit court and deny counselâ€™s request to be relieved.
